fields.name: Intro to Soldering
fields.description: Participants will learn the basic principals of soldering through a hands on course. Including an introduction to the soldering iron and its operation, basic through hole soldering techniques, and many other topics. Participants will learn while assembling two simple project kits.

fields.name: Intro to Java Programming
fields.description: Introduction to the Java language. Material Covered will include Java Syntax(Arithmetic, Types, Control Structures, Inheritance, interfaces, etc) , Object Oriented programming principles, Object Oriented Design Patterns, and Useful Java Libraries. Course will be project based with student learning mainly through completing guided tasks. Prior programming knowledge is helpful but not required.

fields.name: Molecular Biotechniques Crash Course
fields.description:
Have you ever wondered what goes in to creating a Genetically Modified Organism(GMO)?
Learn essential concepts and skills used in biotech labs in this fast paced hands on workshop. We’ll cover the nature of DNA, and the discoveries and breakthroughs that made modifying life forms just another day at the lab. You’ll learn to isolate DNA, cut it with restriction enzymes, transform bacterial cells, perform gel electrophoresis and PCR your own DNA. We’ll also cover new developments in the field, such as synthetic biology and personal genomic data.
This course is geared towards folks with no prior lab experience.

fields.name: Linux OS I
fields.description: An introduction to the Linux Operating System. Interest and experience of the students will help determine the course material. The class will start with basic installation of the Linux Operating System and then cover command line basics to accomplish anything and everything.

fields.name: Advanced MicroControllers
fields.description: The Arduino is a great way to get started in programming microcontrollers. It is cheap, easy to set up and easy to program, but is just one of the tools that are available in the world of physical computing. This course will be an introduction to some of the others. There are tools that are both larger and more powerful and smaller and cheaper then Arduino. They are a little harder to work with, but the extra effort pays big dividends. We will be covering the set-up and use of the GCC compiler for the AVR line of microcontrollers from Atmel. (requires basic knowledge of programming and micro controller theory.)

fields.name: Circuit Theory I
fields.description: This course is the first of a multi part series which will explore basic circuit theory. This course will focus mainly on the foundation principals of analog circuits including voltage, current, resistance, capacitance and other core concepts which will serve as the basis for future classes focusing on more advanced topics.

fields.name: 3D CAD w/ Focus on Rapid Prototyping
fields.description: Students will learn basic and intermediate techniques of 3D CAD (Computer Aided Design&Drafting) and how it is used in rapid prototyping applications. The class will focus on the important concepts of designing parts that can be 3D printed or CNC machined. By the end of the course students will have designed and printed their own 3D parts.

fields.name: Intro to CNC
fields.description: This course will cover the basics of cnc operation using G-Code. Focusing mainly on 3 Axis Machining as our sandbox course participants will learn how to write and debug basic to intermediate G-Code. With the finally products being run on the Lab’s Powerhawk mill.

fields.name: CNC Plasma Cutting with PlasmaCam
fields.description: This course will serve as an intro to anyone interested in using the CNC plasma cutter. The intro will include basic plasmacam software operation, material selection, parameter tuning, and safety considerations.

fields.name: Practical Linear Algebra
fields.description: Course would provide overview of linear algebra with emphasis on basic operations (dot products, cross products, matrix multiplication, etc.) and geometric interpretation of said operations, with the aim of giving students a basic background applicable to tasks faced in mechanical design, programming, and graphics work.

fields.name: OpenGL I
fields.description: Course is a simple introduction to OpenGL’s fixed-function pipeline. Course will cover ways of setting up OpenGL applications (installation of SDKs, etc.), the functioning of the OpenGL rendering pipeline, the creation and drawing of simple shapes, lighting, texturing, coloring, transformations, and other topics as time allows.

fields.name: Welding I
fields.description: Basics of MIG welding. How to weld safely and successfully. Emphasis on providing enough instruction and practice for the beginner to successfully complete a small project. Each Section Limited to 6 participants.

fields.name: Welding II
fields.description: Continuation of Welding I. Emphasis on more advanced techniques with MIG / material selection / basic design for weldments. Intro to TIG time allowing. Each Section Limited to 6 participants.

fields.name: Intro to C Programming
fields.description: This class is for beginning C programmers. It will cover most aspects of the C language including data types, structures, arrays, pointers, arithmetic, bitwise and logical operators, control flow, functions, and some parts of the standard C library for handling strings, i/o, and memory allocation. Students should bring a laptop with a working C compiler, as there will be some hands on exercises. C++ will *not* be covered.

fields.name: Circuit Theory II
fields.description: This course is the second of a multi part series which will explore basic circuit theory. This course will focus mainly on the foundation principals of analog circuits including capacitance, inductance, resonance, transistors and other core concepts which will serve as the basis for future classes focusing on more advanced topics.

fields.name: Intro to Arduino
fields.description: Participants will get a overview of the Arduino’s operation and features and then delve into hands on development learning how to use common sensors and program the Arduino platform. Arduino’s and laptops will be provided. Spaces for this class are limited. (w/ lunch included)
